audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker introducing a video he's creating. He says he wants to "show everyone" and "explain in a little bit of detail" a technology "that has been around for quite some time" and can be used "for automobiles, for engines, for gasoline powered engines."

The audio clip begins with someone talking about fueled engines. They then say, "This is an ultrasonic humidifier," followed by, "I'm gonna read this here to you, how it works." The speaker seems to be providing an explanation or description.

The clip features a single male speaker with a conversational tone, describing a humidifier. He details how the tank feeds water to the misting tray, atomizing it using ultrasonic sound waves and propelling it with a fan. He explains that these pulses are silent, producing a fine mist, and contrasts this type of humidifier with ones that heat water. He indicates the location of the unit inside and mentions its creation of the ultrasound. He describes this technology as ideal and a very good way of vaporizing gasoline.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing how people run their engines off of these, and have been doing so for a long time. He speaks in an informative tone as he explains how to use a unit in a system, saying it needs to sit "a couple inches below the surface of the water," and how it prevents it from turning on without water. He describes how one can bypass this requirement by connecting a wire. The audio clip concludes abruptly.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing the use of gasoline with a specific unit, suggesting one could build a custom system. He explains how the sensor in question would not recognize gasoline as a liquid, requiring a bypass with a ground wire. The speaker mentions the existence of YouTube videos showcasing ultrasonic transducers used to vaporize gasoline and power engines.

The clip features a single male speaker discussing an "ultrasonic transducer humidifier unit." He highlights that it uses "vibrations" and "sound waves" instead of heat to break up the water into a "fine mist" through a process called "cavitation." The speaker speaks in a calm, informative tone.

The audio clip features a single male speaker demonstrating a process. He explains that he's using a jar and shows what happens if he doesn't cover it, which causes splashing. He then covers the jar to prevent splashing and turns something up "all the way." He describes the result as a "very, very fine vapor, extremely fine," emphasizing that this is what's desired when running an engine off of vaporized gasoline. The audio seems to be from a technical demonstration or tutorial. No background music or other sounds are present.

The audio clip features a male speaker, presenting a monologue in a somewhat technical, almost conversational tone, regarding car engines and gasoline. He explains that car engines use liquid gasoline that is not vaporized and suggests that vaporizing the gasoline in the engine could lead to better fuel efficiency, less pollution, and cleaner oil for longer. The speaker emphasizes the goal is to burn the gasoline in the engine itself. He concludes with the fact that they are only allowing vapor.

A male speaker describes putting the unit back on and points out how it creates instant vapor. He notes that this unit is very small, though they make industrial-sized humidifiers and points out that the same ultrasonic transducers can be used to vaporize gasoline. He continues to describe how the gasoline would look similar to the water, but be extremely explosive. He finishes by saying it would just be a cool mist, but would ignite from any flame. The whole time there is the sound of the unit making a light, watery, bubbling noise.

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker wanting to show everyone that the technology is different and does not use heat, but instead ultrasound, referring to a unit. He explains that using gasoline would require grounding the wire and warns about touching the surface of the piece when it's on or running it without liquid, as it could cause an ultrasound burn. He describes the technology as amazing, emphasizing its potential to double the miles per gallon on any vehicle. The speaker mentions that many people are experimenting with this technology and it does work. The speaker shares that the model is a V5100NS and costs just over $50, noting that using these for the house adds humidification. He also mentions that the ultrasonic transducer can be purchased separately online.

The audio clip begins with an "um." A male speaker advises listeners that if they intend to experiment with gasoline, they should be sure to do research and be safe with their testing. The speaker's tone is informative and cautionary. A rattling sound is heard, followed by the speaker saying "thank you."
